data.title: Wrong editor focus when opening settings while code is minimized

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Maybe related to the editor read-only issue...

OS X only
1. Have a single file open
2. Hit <kbd>Cmd M ,</kbd> (that is, keep <kbd>Cmd</kbd> held while you hit <kbd>M</kbd> and <kbd>,</kbd>. Code will minimise
3. Maximise Code. The user settings file will be read-only.

data.title: Spelling problem fixed...
How to detect if a line is visible (in the Viewport)?
data.body:
Hi,

Is there any public API to detect if a `line`, `range` or `position` is currently _visible to the user_ (in the Viewport)? I'm naming _Viewport_ because that's how it appears in `vscode.TextEditorRevealType` (`InCenterIfOutsideViewport`).

Thanks in advance

data.title: editor.wordBasedSuggestions should not be tied to select word (ctrl+D) behavior
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows Server 2012 R2

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Turn off `editor.wordBasedSuggestions` in settings (I did this because overall I find word-based suggestions more annoying than helpful)
2. Open a file (Typescript in my case) and put the cursor inside a string literal
3. Press `ctrl+D` to select the word

Previously, `ctrl+D` would select the word as expected. Now it doesn't unless I turn `editor.wordBasedSuggestions` back on. 

One of the many cases in which this is annoying to me is when renaming a TypeScript import, like `import IFoo from './IFoo'`. I used to put the cursor on the first `IFoo`, press `ctrl+D` to select it, then press `ctrl+D` again to select the second instance inside the string. Now that doesn't work.

If this was an intentional change, it would be nice if the behavior was configurable via a setting.

EDIT: I'm also having trouble with `ctrl+D` not working in other assorted circumstances even with `editor.wordBasedSuggestions` off, sometimes seemingly randomly--it won't work, I'll move the cursor, move it back, and it works.

data.title: "Change All Occurrences" incorrectly accounting for the lack of spaces between matching strings.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.4 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Take the following text:
   
   ```
   abc
   abc abc
   abcabc
   ```
2. Right click the "abc" in the first line to bring up the option to "Change All Occurrences" and select it.
3. Begin typing ("def" for example) to see this result:
   
   ```
   def
   def def
   def
   ```
   
   Although there's a match made between "abcabc" and "abc", the changes are made as if "abcabc" were a single occurrence of "abc".

data.title: Intellisense in go does not work - creates high CPU go process
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: 10.12 Beta (16A270f)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In any context where intellisense should pop-up start typing the name of any existing function
2. Notice intellisense does not show
3. Press Ctrl-Space - a small window pops up that reads "Loading..."
4. Check activity monitor and a process named `go` will be consuming high CPU. No intellisense after waiting at least 1 minute.

If there's any other information I can give to help diagnose this, I'll be happy to provide.

data.title: Extension details view should show extension contributions
data.body:
Extensions can contribute commands to the command palette, editor menus, and the explorer context menu. In addition, commands can be bound to keyboard shortcuts.

The extension details view should give users a way to better understand the contributions an extensions makes and if those contributions cause conflicts with core VS Code keyboard shortcuts or with keyboard shortcuts used by other installed extensions.

data.title: Integrated Terminal Option+Arrow no longer jumps words
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.4

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open Integrated Terminal
2. Use Option/Alt+Left Arrow or Option+Right Arrow

Expected: Cursor moves forward and back words.
Actual: Prints character codes to the terminal line (;3D;3C) for Option+Left, Option+Right

This works as expected in VSCode 1.3.1.

data.title: Git synchronizer does not working after you execute git commands on the integrated terminal

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.4.0 (6276dcb0ae497766056b4c09ea75be1d76a8b679, 2016-08-04T16:49:32.489Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-31-generic

Steps to Reproduce:
1. I've opened the integrated terminal and I've executed the git status command. It has executed successfully.
2. After that I've tried to execute a git synchronization from the git status bar and the following output has been displayed - fatal: Unable to create '/my-project-folder/.git/index.lock': File exists.
3. I've tried to fix it by removing the index.lock file but it seems not exists indeed.

data.title: Autocompletion error when adding #includes with C/C++ extension
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.3.1 - OS Version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04 Steps to Reproduce: 1. With the Microsoft C/C++ Extension installed create a new/ empty .C file 2. Start typing #include . When you reach the end of the line the IDE will attempt to offer autocompletion options, and pressing enter to move to the next line will select the topmost entry in the autocomplete instead of moving to the next line. A mouse click is required to move to the next line, slowing data entry.

data.title: [scss] syntax does not support #{&}
File rename can close editors
data.body:
In some cases we lose an opened editor:
- rename a file that is opened as inactive tab (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9485)
- rename the casing of a file (https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10150)

Note that it is unlikely we can solve this for changes that happen outside of VS Code because file watchers do not know if a file was renamed or not (for them it shows as delete and add).

data.title: Intellisense issue with NODE_PATH evnvironment variable
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.4
- OS Version: Ubuntu 13.10

Steps to Reproduce:

**Project Structure**

```
<project-root>
  + libs
       - utils.js
  - app.js
```

**utils.js**
exports.greetings = function(msg){console.log(msg);}

**app.js**
var utils = require('libs/utils');
utils.greetings('Hello');

The problem is I am not getting intellinsense working properly but the program runs fine if run with :
`NODE_PATH=./ node app`

But the relative require `require('./libs/utils')` gives the intellisense.

data.title: Hidden editors cause issues with keybinding contexts
data.body:
Causing https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/9705 and https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10122

Current thinking is to dispose editors once they become hidden.

data.title: Cannot close pane with cmd+w when tabs are disabled.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0 
- OS Version: OSX 10.10.5

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Disable Tabs by setting the rule `"workbench.editor.showTabs": false` in User settings settings.json
2. Select a file to edit with cmd+p.
3. Repeat step 2 with several different files.
4. Open a new editor pane with cmd+2.
5. Use step 2 in the new pane to open a file for editing.
6. Repeat step 3 in the new pane.
7. Attempt to close the new pane with cmd+w.

Expected Results:
The pane closes using cmd+w.

Actual Results:
cmd+w just closes the the file but the pane (or possibly the editor group?) remains open.

Notes:
This behavior started happening after Tabs was introduced. I've tried `workbench.action.closeAllEditors` and `workbench.action.closeEditorsInGroup` and the pane still will not close.

data.title: syntaxes: end pattern invalidating start pattern
data.body:
is it possible that you can make the end pattern invalidate the start pattern in the syntax files?

for example i am trying to add support to php for php 7 and to be more flexible in the formatting:

``` php
public function
Whatever():
Bool { }
```

because of what appears to be limitations of the syntax engine i cannot quite get this fully pulled off though. the problem seems to be that i cannot tell the difference between a call and a define unless the function name is on the same line as function. it seems to be completely unable to check the line before the current line using any of the regex tricks i can devise.

this lead me to attempting to invalidate the start pattern by using the end pattern. e.g., if end pattern ends with : or { then its a define, else its a call. the problem is that the end pattern does not invalidate the start pattern. so the start pattern will begin highlighting, and if the end pattern is invalid it will break the rest of the file.

this could be done via an additional option to the json for that pattern as to not break all your syntax files, assuming it is possible at all.

data.title: No intellisense for languages for custom files.associations
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 v1511 b10586.494

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Go to https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/overview & observe that intellisense should be possible for custom `files.associations` language options
2. Go to File -> Preferences -> User Settings
3. Add a `files.associations` setting like in the docs (correct quoting & spelling, etc)
4. Attempt to use <kbd>ctrl + space</kbd> to get language options for that part of the setting

The intellisense drop down shows up with the "no suggestions" message. However, I expect it to show language options. This is what the documentation says will happen, as well.

data.title: Dispose editors that get hidden to tackle context issues
